case_vignette: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having this itchy rash on my face and scalp that keeps coming back for the last three months.
How old are you?
I'm 28 years old.
Have you used any new skincare products or hair products recently?
Yes, I started using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months.
Do you have any history of eczema or allergies?
I haven't mentioned any history of eczema or allergies.
Do any of your family members have a history of eczema or skin rashes?
I didn't say anything about my family having skin issues.

Based on your symptoms and history, it sounds like you may be experiencing contact dermatitis caused by the new shaving cream. It is important to stop using that product and see if the symptoms improve. If not, consider seeing a dermatologist for further evaluation.
